article:

Yes, it is. A recent study arranged by Kleenex on how the British express their emotions   _   that 95 percent of them still   _   their emotions.
Moreover,   _   72 percent think this is unhealthy, 19 percent can't remember the last time they "let it out". As a result, Kleenex is   _   the "Let It Out" campaign that   _   Britons to grab a tissue and have a good cry.
These days, however, the male Briton's   _   toward crying is changing. Though the majority still   _   to open up emotionally, a 2004 study by Oxford's Social Issues Research Center found that 77 percent of British men considered crying in public increasingly   _  . Half of London males   _   crying in front of their mothers. Scotsmen are the least emotional, although they are the most   _   to cry at weddings.
Peter Marsh, director of the center, said: "Crying can now indicate sensitivity rather than    _  . Like David Beckham, crying because you're dropping off your boy at nursery isn't seen as weak."
Winston Churchill was said to be a   _   crier, shedding tears at seeing a 41 _  in an air raid shelter  , and when he saw his wife after a long   _   .
Psychologists say that while society has accepted that men can cry, there are   _  . Ronald Bracey, a consulting psychologist, said: "If a man began to cry when he was having stitches   in hospital, he would be   _   as a wimp  . Men still need to be seen as strong when it   _   to physical pain."
